case_name: Jyoti Bhushan Gupta and Gokul Chand v. Official Liquidator, Banaras Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 198 of 1956 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil APPEAL No. 198 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated August 24, 1950, of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 399 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 24, 1950, of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 399 of 1947.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SHAH, J. on October 12, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. October l 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Banaras Bank Ltd. is a public limited company having its registered office at Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The Banaras Bank Ltd.-a public limited companypany having its registered office at Banaras- hereinafter referred to as the Bank

facts.text: Banaras Bank Ltd. was ordered on March 1, 1940 to be compulsorily wound up by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: was ordered on March l, 1 940 to be companypulsorliy wound up by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, and the Official Liquidator was appointed

facts.text: Official Liquidator was appointed to conduct the proceedings in winding up of Banaras Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: and the Official Liquidator was appointed to companyduct the proceedings in winding up.

facts.text: On September 12, 1942, High Court made an order under s. 187 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 for payment of unpaid calls.

anchor.surface_text: On September 12, 1942, an order was made by the High Court under s. 187 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913  VII of 1913  for payment of unpaid calls

facts.text: Appellants Jyoti Bhushan Gupta and Gokul Chand had names placed on the list of contributories.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants Jyoti Bhushan Gupta. and Gokul Chand, whose names had been placed on the list of companytributors,

facts.text: Appellants Jyoti Bhushan Gupta and Gokul Chand were directed to pay Rs. 95,178/5/9 with interest to the Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: were directed to pay with interest Rs. 95,178/5/9 to the official Liquidator of the Bank.

facts.text: The order of September 12, 1942 was enforceable as a decree of the High Court by virtue of s. 199 of the Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: This order was, by virtue of s. 199 of the Act, enforceable in the manner in which the decree of the High Court made in any suit pending therein may be enforced.

facts.text: On September 12, 1946, the order was transferred to the District Judge, Allahabad for execution.

anchor.surface_text: On September 12, 1946, the order was transferred to the District Judge, Allahabad for execution.

facts.text: On September 23, 1946, the Official Liquidator applied to the District Court, Allahabad for execution of the order dated September 12, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1946, the official Liquidator applied to the District Court, Allahabad for execution of the order dated September 12, 1942, and prayed

facts.text: Official Liquidator prayed for attachment of certain amounts due to the appellants in satisfaction of the claim.

anchor.surface_text: and prayed that certain amounts due to the appellants be attached in satisfaction of the claim.

facts.text: Execution proceedings were transferred by the District Judge to the Civil Judge, Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings were transferred by the District Judge to the Civil Judge, Allahabad.

facts.text: Appellants contended that the application for execution was not preferred within 3 years of the order and was barred by Art. 182 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended Inter alia that as the application for execution was number preferred within 3 years of the order for payment as prescribed by Art. 182

facts.text: Official Liquidator contended that the application was governed by Art. 183 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The official Liquidator companytended that the application was governed by Art. 183 of the Act

facts.text: Official Liquidator contended that certain part payments by appellants extended the period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: and that, in any event, certain part payments having been made towards the claim by the appellants, the period of limitation was extended thereby.

facts.text: At the hearing, the alternative plea of part payment was abandoned by the Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing, the alternative plea of part payment was abandoned by the Official Liquidator.

facts.text: Civil Judge held that the application for execution was barred by limitation as not preferred within 3 years from the order.

anchor.surface_text: The Civi1 Judge held that the application for execution was barred limitation as it was number preferred within 3 years from the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed the order of the Civil Judge and remitted the proceedings to the Civil Judge to restore the execution application and proceed according to law.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Allahabad, the order passed by the Civil Judge was reversed and the proceedings were remitted to the Civil Judge with a direction to restore the execution application to its original number and to proceed with it according to law.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order with certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 133 of the Constitution, this appeal is preferred.

facts.text: No notification conferring jurisdiction on District Court at Banaras under Companies Act for s.187 orders was issued.

anchor.surface_text: But it is companymon ground that numbernotification companyferring jurisdiction and empowering the District Court at Banaras-where the registered office of the companypany is situate-to pass orders under B. 187 has been issued.

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Allahabad was the Court competent to direct payment under s.187.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore the only Court companypetent to direct under B. 187 of the Indian Companies Act payment of the amount due from the appellants.

arguments.claim: Execution application filed by Official Liquidator within limitation under Art.183.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the application for execution filed by the official Liquidator was within limitation.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the application for execution filed by the official Liquidator was within limitation.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right ill holding that the application for execution filed by the official Liquidator was within limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution application governed by Art. 183 (12 years) rather than Art. 182 (3 years) because High Court order under s. 187 Companies Act passed in ordinary original civil jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction exercised by the High Court under s. 187 Companies Act is ordinary, original and civil.

anchor.surface_text: This jurisdiction may be invoked as of right against all persons whose names are placed on the list of contributories. The jurisdiction is ordinary it does number depend on any extraordinary action on the part of the High Court. The jurisdiction is also original in character because the petition for exercise of the jurisdiction is entertainable by the High Court as a court of first instance and number in exercise of its appellate jurisdiction. Again by s. 187 numberspecial jurisdiction is companyferred. The High Court adjudicates upon the liability of the debtor to pay debts due by him to the Company the jurisdiction is therefore civil.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction ordinary (as of right, no special steps), original (first instance), civil (adjudicates debt liability); not extraordinary or special despite statutory vesting.

holdings.text: By s. 3 read with s. 187 of the Companies Act the High Court has jurisdiction to direct payment of the amount due by a contributory and an order passed for payment manifestly is an order passed in exercise of the jurisdiction vested in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 3 read with s. 187 of the Companies Act the High Court has jurisdiction to direct payment of the amount due by a contributory and an order passed for payment manifestly is an order passed in exercise of the jurisdiction vested in the High Court by s. 3 read with 8. 187 of the Companies Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation: s.3 defines court jurisdiction, s.187 vests power to order payment which is jurisdiction, not mere power; enforceable as decree under s.199.

holdings.text: We are of the view that the appeal must fail on the merits.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the appeal must fail on the merits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution application within limitation under Art. 183; High Court order correctly restored for execution.

holdings.text: The order under s.187 was passed by the High Court which was the only Court competent as no notification empowering District Court at Banaras issued.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore the only Court competent to direct under B. 187 of the Indian Companies Act payment of the amount due from the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 Companies Act vests jurisdiction in High Court at registered office place unless notified otherwise for District Court; no such notification.
